texts.shortText:
Large and conspicuous solitary ascidian found mostly in sheltered sites and sometimes rooted in sand. The test (outer covering) is distinctively raised into pointed papillae around the siphons (distinguishing it from the otherwise similar and much more common P. stolonifera). Live specimens often heavily encrusted with fouling organisms.

When cut it has a rigid whitish inner layer covered with a thin red to brown ‘skin’. The prominent inhalant siphon points upwards and the exhalent one projects laterally on the ‘shoulder’. The flesh is pink to bright red (hence the common name ‘red bait’).

Global: Namibia, South Africa and Morocco.

Local/Regional: Namibia to southern KwaZulu-Natal.

Less common than the closely related P. stolonifera and mostly found in sheltered sites. Although primarily on rocks or jetties etc., they can occur on soft substrata (see photo below) and then the test is extended downward into the sediment in the form of long tapering ‘roots’ that anchor the animal into the substratum.

The structure of the outer test of this and related ascidians is interesting as it is composed of cellulose, a material normally associated with plants and found only in this group of animals. Cellulose may be a good choice for a protective coating, as few animals have enzymes capable of digesting this material!

All ascidians are filter feeders, drawing seawater in thought the inhalant siphon and filtering this though a net of mucous, which is continuously generated and passed across the mesh-like walls of the pharynx, before being rolled up and into a threadlike cord and transported to the oesophagus.

Most ascidians are hermaphroditic and although colonial species expand their colonies via asexual reproduction (budding), solitary ones reproduce only by broadcast spawning. Eggs and sperm are released into the water, where fertilization takes place and the unusual tadpole larvae develop.

Ascidian larvae are famous for revealing the chordate affinities of the group, which are hard to appreciate by examining the rather degenerate-looking sedentary adults!

Ascidian larvae have a distinct tail and notocord (primitive ‘backbone’) and swim actively. When they are ready to settle they attach themselves to the substratum with adhesive papillae on the head and resorb the tail and notochord, effectively rotating the body 180 degrees so that the ‘mouth’ or inhalant siphon, now points upwards.

Pyura species are easy to distinguish from other regional ascidians due to their large size and thick, red to brown-skinned tests. This species can easily be confused with P. stolonifera though, which is very similar in size and habits, but lacks the lobed papillae around the siphons.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 246).

Monniot, C, Monniot, F, Griffiths, CL & Schleyer, M (2001). South African ascidians. Annals of the South African Museum, 108(1), 1-141 (p. 114).
